paper_abstract: Models for complex systems are often built with more parameters than can be uniquely identified by the available data. Because of the variety of causes, identifying a lack of parameter identifiability typically requires the mathematical manipulation of models, Monte Carlo simulations, and examination of the Fisher Information Matrix. A simple test for parameter estimability is introduced, using Data Cloning, a Markov Chain Monte Carlo based algorithm. Together, Data cloning and the ANOVA based test determine if the model parameters are estimable and if so, determine their maximum likelihood estimates and provide the asymptotic standard errors. When not all model parameters are estimable, the Data Cloning results and the ANOVA test can be used to determine estimable parameter combinations or infer identifiability problems in the model structure. The method is illustrated using three different real data systems that are known to be difficult to analyze. Crown Copyright (C) 2013 Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: An ANOVA test for parameter estimability using data cloning with application to statistical inference for dynamic systems
